text: Next time, climb Calton hill at the back of your hotel in Waterloo place - your stop in Edinburgh.  It's not much of a climb, but it affords a great view of the castle, Arthur's seat, and much of the city, and there is a fabulous structure at the top - I won't give away what it is.  Blackford hill is also a modest climb, with views again of course, and the Hermitage at the back of the hill is a beautiful fairly wild wood to walk through near the heart of the city.   I'm sure you'd appreciate all of that!
author: @jonathancowan2251

author: @Franibascur

text:
Plus one for road trips. There is nothing better than seeing the countryside, architecture and culture change as you just go along on your merry way.  I'm fortunate enough to live in the UK, so one of the things I love doing is finishing work early, getting in the (prepacked) car and going for a long drive with my partner, with just the ferry tickets booked in advance and a vague idea of where we want to go and how to get there. Get to a place, find a camp site, pitch the tent and go and explore. Stay for a night, or if you like it, stay for two. Or maybe three.

Most recent road trip was in August, when we ended up driving all the way to Montenegro and back again (12 countries in total). This was maybe our 8th such trip, we try and visit new places each time. In 2021 we toured Scotland. I'm ashamed to say that it was the first time we had done this (considering I'm originally from Scotland). It wasn't quite the NC500, as we veered off course through the Cairngorms to visit family, then to Orkney, up to the far north west then Skye and all bits in between.  It was the only time that I have felt myself close to tears whilst driving, due to the awe inspiring surroundings.
